text:
Hi, I get a lot of emails asking for link building. For the ones that are relevant and have a higher DA than my site, can I request that I get a link as well?

Also, is it bad to have the articles link to one another?

elements.text:
Hi, I get a lot of emails asking for link building. For the ones that are relevant and have a higher DA than my site, can I request that I get a link as well?

Also, is it bad to have the articles link to one another?

text:
I'd 100% ask for _something_ in return.

Historically, it's been thought that blatant link swapping is bad practice. So three-way swapping is good practice if you don't want to risk it.

I.e. you might have another site or a guest post that you link to instead (or they do).

If the brand has a large/relevant audience, I sometimes ask for them to share the post on social or include in their newsletter.

elements.text: I'd 100% ask for
something

in return.

Historically, it's been thought that blatant link swapping is bad practice. So three-way swapping is good practice if you don't want to risk it.

I.e. you might have another site or a guest post that you link to instead (or they do).

If the brand has a large/relevant audience, I sometimes ask for them to share the post on social or include in their newsletter.

text: Good to know, thanks <@UJJFDTN8G>!

elements.text: Good to know, thanks

text: If you're doing it between two big reputable sites with tons of links going in and out, you're fine with asking for a link to a different article in return.

elements.text: If you're doing it between two big reputable sites with tons of links going in and out, you're fine with asking for a link to a different article in return.

text: Google says lots of things are “bad” because they work. :wink:

elements.text: Google says lots of things are “bad” because they work.

text: A few links swap here and there won’t hurt you. I’m doing this between properties owned by the same client and the rankings are only going up. However make sure you review the site and is not a bad quality or some cheap PBN. Also you might want to keep track of the links you get because they might remove it in the future.

elements.text: A few links swap here and there won’t hurt you. I’m doing this between properties owned by the same client and the rankings are only going up. However make sure you review the site and is not a bad quality or some cheap PBN. Also you might want to keep track of the links you get because they might remove it in the future.

text: I do this, <@U02LGA1DB9N>! If they decline the link swap, I ask if they'd want to do a guest post swap.

elements.text: I do this,
! If they decline the link swap, I ask if they'd want to do a guest post swap.

text: Good to know <@U016NBFS16Y> about tracking and PBN’s! I am so new to all of this :sob:

text: anyone got a playbook/checklist for promoting podcasts? organic moreso than paid.

elements.text: anyone got a playbook/checklist for promoting podcasts? organic moreso than paid.

text:
I'd put most of it in the same bag as blog posts. Where do people go for information?
Where does your audience hang out?
Who do they follow?

I've not seen one specifically for podcasts - though I know a man that could make this course.

You might find some ideas in my post on content promotion

<https://dominickent.medium.com/content-promotion-strategies-e5b69bd29c7b>

attachments.title: 40 Actionable Content Promotion Strategies [With Examples]
attachments.text: You’ve written a post designed to take organic traffic by storm. What do you do next? Sit back and wait for the SEO goodness to do its…
attachments.fallback: Medium: 40 Actionable Content Promotion Strategies [With Examples]

elements.text:
I'd put most of it in the same bag as blog posts. Where do people go for information?
Where does your audience hang out?
Who do they follow?

I've not seen one specifically for podcasts - though I know a man that could make this course.

You might find some ideas in my post on content promotion

text: We repurpose ours on the blog pretty often and see some success with that! Here's a recent example: <https://marketerhire.com/blog/scaling-eventbrite-marketing-team>

elements.text: We repurpose ours on the blog pretty often and see some success with that! Here's a recent example:

text:
Yep, definitely repurpose as blog posts and provide transcriptions.

Also, be a guest on other podcasts. The best way to find other podcast listeners is, as you might imagine, podcasts! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Yep, definitely repurpose as blog posts and provide transcriptions.

Also, be a guest on other podcasts. The best way to find other podcast listeners is, as you might imagine, podcasts!

text:
You can get so much mileage out of one podcast episode!

:white_check_mark: The podcast itself

:white_check_mark: A blog post or notes page for each episode (great notes page template here: <https://www.linkedin.com/posts/tristanpelligrino_podcasting-marketing-activity-6859824825171484673-Dz1b/>)

:white_check_mark: YouTube video for each episode

:white_check_mark: Video/audio clips

:white_check_mark: Quote cards

You can promote all of these on your regular distribution channels (newsletter, social, etc.) and ask each episode guest to do the same.

elements.text: You can get so much mileage out of one podcast episode!

You can promote all of these on your regular distribution channels (newsletter, social, etc.) and ask each episode guest to do the same.

text: I almost always have a YouTube video embedded on a blog post for Mio. Could do the same for podcast - or clips from it.

elements.text: I almost always have a YouTube video embedded on a blog post for Mio. Could do the same for podcast - or clips from it.

text:
Hey everyone!

We had an early launch of our Black Friday sale to avoid the rush. We offer online legal assistance to small businesses and this is our busiest time of the year. Unfortunately our email campaigns aren't performing the way they usually do (talking of last 5 years data) and the leads aren't picking up. What are the things to evaluate here? I'd appreciate any tips to salvage the campaign!

elements.text:
Hey everyone!

We had an early launch of our Black Friday sale to avoid the rush. We offer online legal assistance to small businesses and this is our busiest time of the year. Unfortunately our email campaigns aren't performing the way they usually do (talking of last 5 years data) and the leads aren't picking up. What are the things to evaluate here? I'd appreciate any tips to salvage the campaign!

text: What's the quality of your list like? Have you got all warm leads on there? And what's the offer like? Could it be possible that the people on your email list don't need your offer as they are already customers of yours?

elements.text: What's the quality of your list like? Have you got all warm leads on there? And what's the offer like? Could it be possible that the people on your email list don't need your offer as they are already customers of yours?

text: Have you tried take your best performing campaigns from the last 5 years and tweeting it slightly and sending that out. You know it performed well before so it's likely it could again

elements.text: Have you tried take your best performing campaigns from the last 5 years and tweeting it slightly and sending that out. You know it performed well before so it's likely it could again

text:
Hey <@U02CTCZEL3E> thanks for jumping in here! The offer is sent to both customers and non-customers (interacted with us but didn't sign-up) as there's both a sign-up or upgrade option available.

I like the idea of sending the best performing campaign a shot. Thanks! :heart:

elements.text: Hey

thanks for jumping in here! The offer is sent to both customers and non-customers (interacted with us but didn't sign-up) as there's both a sign-up or upgrade option available.

I like the idea of sending the best performing campaign a shot. Thanks!

text: Also maybe split the campaign up into two for customers and non customers so you can personalise your message to them more maybe?

elements.text: Also maybe split the campaign up into two for customers and non customers so you can personalise your message to them more maybe?

text: Segmentation is always great for conversions in emails

elements.text: Segmentation is always great for conversions in emails
